analyzed: jātaka  pakiṇṇaka nipāta  sāli kedāra vagga
translated: Jātaka Stories🔽The Minor Collection🔽The Chapter with Sālika and the Deer
The Story of the Skinned Hog
“When we were wandering about,
mountains and forests,
searching for our relatives,
we found them.
There’s plenty of roots and fruits here,
and this food is not in short supply.
These mountain slopes are delightful,
and we’ll have a comfortable stay.
I’ll stay right here
with all my relatives.
Without concern or worry,
without grief or fear.”
“Look for another shelter,
for there’s a predator here.
He kills the skinned hogs
that come here, one by one.”
“Who’s the predator here,
who’s the relative of those who’ve come together?
Who kills those who are hard to kill?
Tell me this, when asked.”
“The king of beasts, the king of animals,
the powerful, tusked, weaponed beast,
kills the skinned hogs
that come here, one by one.”
“We’re not without tusks,
and we’re strong.
All of us together,
we will live alone”.
“What goes to the heart, what is pleasing to the ear,
is the speech you speak, it is true;
Even if one were to run away in battle,
we would kill him later”.
“Are you today refraining from killing living creatures,

translated: “Not the king, not the robber,
not the tiger, lord of beasts,
but when kinsmen are united
the tiger is brought under control.”
“The owls and the crows,
living in flocks and herds,
in mutual agreement,
fly up and fall down.
And when they are falling down,

analyzed: ekettha apasakkati  tat ca senaḥ nitāḷa iti
translated: one of them will fail,🔽and the king-crow will pick him off,
for that is his nature.”
“Urged on by the ascetic,
greedy for the sight of flesh,
the boar went to the boars,
thinking as before.”
“Good are the many kinsmen,
even the trees of the forest;
but when the boars were united,
the tiger was killed in the one path.”🔽The boars killed both
the brahmin and the tiger.
They were delighted and joyful,
and they let out a great cry.
Those boars, well assembled
at the foot of the udumbara tree,
anointed the boar Tacchaka,
saying: “You are our king and lord.”
The Tacchaka Boar Jātaka is the ninth.
